ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

AHMAD IBRAHIM INTEGRATED
SECONDARY SCHOOL
(Malay Secondary School classes)


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Education whether he proposes to start Malay Secondary School classes at the Ahmad Ibrahim Integrated Secondary School, Sembawang Hill, for the Malay stream students living in the Sembawang Constituency.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, Malay medium secondary classes have not been started at the Ahmad Ibrahim Integrated Secondary School because of the relatively small demand

Column: 604

for Malay medium secondary places in this area. For the years 1960 to 1966, the number of pupils from Sembawang Malay schools who qualified for Secondary I Malay medium was 45, 50, 45, 36, 77, 68 and 63 respectively. It will be seen that each year the number was too small even to start two classes. Lack of adequate staff at the higher level and subject teaching requirements call for a wise deployment of Malay medium secondary teachers, and we are very short of qualified Malay medium secondary school teachers. A minimum of four classes of Secondary I would be necessary to make the best use of staffing facilities and for effective teaching. The Sembawang Malay medium secondary students are posted mainly to Monk's Hill Secondary School to which they can go by one bus. The majority of them are receiving bus bursaries. In view of these circumstances, it is not proposed to start Malay medium secondary classes in the Ahmad Ibrahim Integrated Secondary School, at least not until the demand increases to make possible the formation of four classes.

CHANGING OF STREET AND
KAMPONG NAMES
(Government policy)


    2. Mr Bernard Rodrigues asked the Minister for Finance what is the policy in regard to changes of the names of streets and kampongs, and whether the residents concerned are consulted when any changes of street or kampong names are proposed.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, as a rule, names of streets that are existent are generally retained. In the choice of names for new streets and kampongs, the former practice of using colonial and snob names, or names of royalty, has been discontinued. The present practice is to choose names which may relate to the historical background or the physical features of the area, or to use names of local flora or fauna.

Column: 605



    It is not the practice specifically to consult the residents of an area, but suggestions received from the public are given consideration.

INCOME TAX DEPARTMENT
(Reasons for resignations)


    3. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Finance what is the rate of resignations from the Income Tax Department and whether the rate is high when compared with the rate in other departments; and if he will give the reasons for the resignations.

    Mr Ramaswamy (for the Minister for Finance): Resignations in the middle seniority grades have occurred and the reasons are generally that of better remuneration offered in non-Government employment outside or for less onerous and exacting work. Over the last three years, the resignations have been as follows: 

               1966    Division I - 

                           2 Assessment Officers 

                                for better remuneration outside;

                           One Probationary Legal Officer, 

                                who is a non-citizen, left after 

                                serving less than six months' service;

               1965    Nil.

               1964    Nil.


In the lower seniority grade, resignations have been due to failure to pass examinations required for confirmation of their appointment and for better pay.

    1966 Division II - Assistant Examiners. Out of the eight who resigned, six left to better their prospects in non-Government employment; one for further studies and one left to join her husband overseas.

    Division III - Clerical Officers. Seven resigned. Of these, two left for better pay, one was selected to undergo a training Officer's Course in the Singapore Armed Forces, three left to undertake further studies, and one obtained a bursary for study at the Teachers' Training College.

Column: 606



    Division IV Typists, Process and Notice Servers, Office Boys - one each. The typist left for alternative employment with better pay. The Process and Notice Server left for reasons unknown. The Office Boy left for alternative employment at higher pay.

    1965 Division II - Assistant Examiners. Six resigned. Three left for alternative employment with better pay, and three left to undertake further studies.

    Division III - Clerical Officers. Eleven resigned. Four of these left for alternative employment with better pay; four left for further studies, one left to get married, and two left because they failed to pass the examinations.

    1964 Division II Assistant Examiners. Four resigned. Two left for alternative employment with better pay; one was awarded an overseas scholarship to undertake professional studies overseas and he has since returned to the department, and one left on account of failing to pass the departmental examination.

    Executive Officers. One resigned for alternative employment with better pay.

    1964 Division III Assistant Examiners-in-training. Three resigned to undertake further studies, one left as he failed to pass the examinations.

    Clerical Officers. One left for alternative employment as he failed to pass his examination.

    Division IV - Typists. One resigned to accompany her husband on transfer to Kuala Lumpur.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): A supplementary question, Sir. Apart from the reason given of better emoluments from outside, is it a fact that the Income Tax Department is the only department in the Government that has the greatest rate of resignations?

    Mr Speaker: Can the Parliamentary Secretary answer that without notice?

Column: 607



    Mr Ramaswamy: I do not think so.

    Mr Tang See Chim (Choa Chu Kang): A supplementary question, Sir. What is the Government going to do about this brain-drain from Government departments?

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is always impossible to prevent people from leaving Government departments. Whether it is a brain-drain or not is open to contention. On our side, we are quite happy that some of them left us. The Government can do without them and we will get better ones later on.

    Mr Ho See Beng: I would like to ask the Minister whether there is any possibility that the Head of Department, in dealing with the junior officers, has failed in his human relationship and that this has brought about this high rate of resignations in the Income Tax Department?

    Mr Lim Kim San: I do not know what rate of resignations the hon. Member for Bras Basah will consider to be a high rate. From the figures given, I think it is quite a normal rate. In fact, most of them resigned because of higher pay or to further their studies, and I think they should thank the Commissioner of Inland Revenue, for they are able to get better emoluments outside because of the training that he had given them while they were in service.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not saying that the Income Tax Department has got a high rate of resignations. I am asking, is it a fact that this department, compared to other departments, has got a high rate of resignations? The Minister for Finance, as his post in the Government is more or less like that of an employer, should know whether other departments have the same rate of resignations?

    Mr Lim Kim San: If the Member would like a comparative table of resignations from other departments, I will supply it later on. But I am quite satisfied with the personal relationship that is existing between the head of that department and the staff, The Income

Column: 608

Tax Department is a little bit peculiar in that it requires a greater amount of output and productivity from the staff. It is quite a rigorous department in that we are dealing with entrepreneurs who are very astute in finding ways and means of wriggling out of their income tax responsibility. Therefore, the people who work there require greater acumen, greater drive and greater interest in their work.

INCOME TAX DEPARTMENT
(Grouses about working conditions)


    4. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Finance if he has received any representations, or has any knowledge of grouses among the junior officers of the Income Tax Department about working conditions in that Department, and what action he has taken, or proposes to take, in the matter.

    Mr Ramaswamy (for the Minister for Finance): Officers have from time to time complained of being asked to work harder than the staff in other Government departments and occasionally of having to work outside normal office hours during peak periods.

    This is to be expected as taxation work is both exacting and onerous. During peak periods the staff will occasionally have to work extra time, but this is offset by a freer time during off-peak periods.

    Mr Ho See Beng: I am not quite satisfied with the answer of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance. What I am asking is whether he has received any grouses from the staff of the Income Tax Department, and if he has, what steps he has taken to remedy the grouses?

    Mr Ramaswamy: Their complaints are of being asked to work hard and occasionally having to work outside normal hours. That is all.

    Mr Speaker: I think the supplementary question is really directed at asking if there have been grouses other than those relating to overwork or work outside office hours,

Column: 609



    Mr Ramaswamy: Not that I am aware of, Sir.

FLATS IN JURONG INDUSTRIAL ESTATE


    5. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Finance if he will request the Economic Development Board to furnish him with information on (a) the number of flats built by the Board in the Jurong Industrial Estate; (b) what is the rental charged; (c) how many flats are occupied; and (d) whether steps have been taken to encourage factory workers in the area to occupy the vacant flats; and if he will furnish the House with the information.

    Mr Ramaswamy (for the Minister for Finance): The Economic Development Board has so far built 4,512 units in the residential zone of the Jurong Industrial Estate. Of this number, 2,614 units are occupied. The rates of rental are $20 per month for a one-room flat; $46.50 per month for a two-room flat; and $66.50 per month for a three-room flat, inclusive of service and conservancy charges. These are the rates of rental applicable only to Singapore citizens with a family income of less than $800 per month. Singapore citizens whose family income is more than $800 are only eligible for three-room flats and are charged a rental of $91.50 per month. Further, flats may also be let out to non-Singapore citizens on the specific approval of the Economic Development Board. Rentals applicable to non-Singapore citizens are $106.50 for a three-room flat; $66.50 for a two-room flat, and $30 for a one-room flat. It will be noted that while rentals for workers who are Singapore citizens are at subsidised rates, non-Singapore citizens with work permits have to pay the full economic rental if they wish to stay in the flats at the Jurong Industrial Estate.

    In planning the development of the Jurong Industrial Estate, the Economic Development Board aims at building up a self-contained community. Low-cost housing is therefore built so that workers may stay near their places of work and need not commute from other

Column: 610

areas of Singapore to Jurong, which may involve journeys of 20 miles or more a day. The Board's policy, therefore, is to encourage as many workers as possible to stay in the flats at the Jurong Industrial Estate.

    The housing estate at Taman Jurong is provided with markets, a school, shops, a playground, a football field as well as a community centre. Early next year an open-air cinema will be built there.

    In leasing out lands to industries in Singapore, a clause is inserted which requires all lessees to try to house their workers at Taman Jurong in the industrial estate. Manufacturing and other firms located at Jurong are regularly informed of the availability of low-cost housing for their workers. Industrial firms themselves are also encouraging their workers to stay in Jurong by granting housing allowances in lieu of a transport allowance.

    Mr Tang See Chim: A supplementary, Mr Speaker, Sir. Is it true that the flats at Jurong are at present half empty and that there was only one registration at the school there and that at present it is being put to other uses?

    Mr Speaker: Part of that question should, of course, be addressed to the Minister for Education. But, Mr Ramaswamy, do you want to reply to that part to which you can reply?

    Mr Ramaswamy: I have given the figures of occupation of these flats. There are 4,512 units. Of this number, 2,614 units are occupied. Of course, the hon. Member can calculate whether it is half or more than half.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues (Telok Blangah): A supplementary question, Sir. In view of the low wages paid in Jurong, what is the Minister doing to encourage employers to subsidise the rents in Jurong?

    Mr Lim Kim San: These are already subsidised rates of rental charged to workers who are Singapore citizens. I think at the moment in Jurong most of the workers are either given free transport or a transport allowance, so that

Column: 611

if they desire to live in Taman Jurong, they will get, in lieu of free transport, a transport allowance, which is a form of subsidy towards paying their rental. In fact, in some cases it may be almost the rental of a one-room unit.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: A supplementary, Mr Speaker. I think the Minister is wrong, because in most cases in Jurong they do not subsidise, neither do they give a transport allowance. They leave it to the union to fight. So I am hoping the Minister will do something to encourage future developers in Jurong really to help the workers in the subsidy of rent. In fact, I understand the policy of providing transport has been stopped for quite some time now.

    Mr Lim Kim San: I will not argue about the policy of the labour union with regard to a subsidy for transport or a subsidy for houses. But I would like the hon. Member to remember that we are, at the moment, engaged in the task of increasing productivity and lowering costs. If the entrepreneurs in Jurong find that it is possible to give additional pay, either in the form of a housing allowance or in any other form, and be still able to compete externally, then the union will have a good case. Otherwise, I think it will have to hold its horses for the time being.

    Mr Tang See Chim: A supplementary, Sir. Does the Minister not consider that the giving of a transport subsidy would, in fact, encourage people to stay away from Jurong rather than stay in Jurong?

    Mr Ramaswamy: I have just said that the employers are requested to pay a housing allowance instead of a transport allowance, and most of them are doing that.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: A supplementary, Mr Speaker. Has the Parliamentary Secretary investigated how many employers are subsidising house rents in Jurong? I am quite sure he is not aware, Mr Speaker.

    Mr Ramaswamy: I am not aware. But this is what the Government or the

Column: 612

Economic Development Board is doing, asking employers to pay a housing allowance instead of a transport allowance.

    Mr Lim Kim San: A point of clarification, Sir. It is not the Government or the Housing Board that has asked employers to pay a housing allowance in lieu of a transport allowance. I think the Member for Telok Blangah must be aware that where workers have been receiving a transport allowance, this has been termed a housing allowance if they stay in Jurong. To reply to the Member opposite, it is not Government's policy to encourage employers to pay a housing allowance, because in one way it prevents the workers from staying in Jurong, which is exactly opposite to what we intend. We have spent a lot of money on the infrastructure in Jurong and we would like the workers to turn it into a town.

TRADE BETWEEN SINGAPORE AND AFRICAN COUNTRIES


    6. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Finance since the Trade Mission to Africa what is the progress of trade between Singapore and the African countries.

    Mr Ramaswamy (for the Minister for Finance): The Trade Mission to Africa visited seven African States in March and April this year. Since its return, a continuous flow of trade inquiries from Africa has been received. Individual merchants from Africa have also visited Singapore and concluded business with our own manufacturers and traders. The Manager of the Zambian Trade Fair recently came here to persuade our manufacturers to participate in the Zambian Trade Fair to be held next year. We would consider favourably participation in this Fair.

    Trade between several African countries and ourselves has shown encouraging increases. These countries are the United Arab Republic, Kenya, Zambia, Malawi and Tanzania. An increasing amount and variety of locally manufactured goods are finding markets in Africa. Exports of products such as tyres, tubes and steel pipes have shown

Column: 613

substantial increases in the first 11 months of this year, compared with the same period last year. For instance, exports of tyres and tubes increased from $121,000 in 1965 to $674,000 this year. Similarly, exports of steel pipes have increased from $40,000 last year to $330,000 this year. We are confident that with active export promotion, our goods will find ready acceptance in African markets in terms of price, quality as well as delivery.

NATIONAL REGISTRATION FOR
NEW IDENTITY CARDS


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Labour when the National Registration for the new identity card will be completed, and what are the latest available breakdown figures in respect of citizens and non-citizens of the Republic.

    The Acting Minister for Labour (Mr E. W. Barker): The registration for new plastic laminated identity cards is expected to be completed by the end of the year. The latest available breakdown figures up to and including the 25th November this year are as follows: 

                     Citizens            1,041,330

                     Non-citizens          125,376


    Mr Ho See Beng: Is the Minister aware that prior to the pronouncement of Government regarding citizens by descent, those who have passed the age of 21 have to take an oath of allegiance, or else they would not be entitled to apply for citizenship? I understand that a number of this category of citizens who went to the Identity Card Office to change their identity cards were not allowed to change their identity cards. Is the Minister aware of this matter?

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, this matter raised by the Member for Bras Basah, in my view, is completely irrelevant to the question I am answering. But if he will put another question to the House, I will be prepared to answer it some other day. This is a question on the number of citizens and non-citizens who have been registered. I am not aware of the cases to which the Member has referred.

Column: 614



    Mr Speaker: I think Mr Ho's question deals with problems that have arisen since last Friday as a result of the Constitution Modification Order.

    Mr Barker: That is correct. Surely it does not come under this head.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I know it is not very relevant, but I think it is relevant in this connection, that all those citizens who have passed the age of 21 prior to the pronouncement of Government about citizens by descent have to take an oath of allegiance. When these people went to the Identity Card Office to apply for a change of identity card, they were rejected. What are we going to do with these rejected persons?

    Mr Barker: I am not aware of any such citizens who have been so rejected. But if any such case should arise, I can assure the Member for Bras Basah that any such person claiming citizenship by descent will be given the opportunity to swear allegiance if he has not sworn allegiance in the past. Perhaps the Member is referring to cases who have passed the age of 22. They are supposed to swear within the one-year period. I think the Member is worried about such cases. I can assure him that even in those cases the persons concerned will be given every opportunity to swear an oath of allegiance.

    Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng (Joo Chiat): I understand there are a number of aliens in this country, Sir, with forged new identity cards. Is the Minister aware of that?

    Mr Barker: No, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware of any cases of forged new identity cards. There are many cases of forged old identity cards. One of the objects of introducing the new laminated identity cards is to prevent easy forgery. If what the Member for Joo Chiat is saying is true, it must be rather disturbing and I will be happy to investigate any such allegations.

    Mr Speaker: I am sure the House is grateful to the Minister in his condition for having gone outside the ambit of the original question.

PROTECTION OF PIECE-RATED
WORKERS UNDER EMPLOYMENT LAWS


    8. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Labour if he will consider introducing amending legislation to enable all categories of piece-rated workers to have equal rights of protection under the employment laws.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, under the existing employment laws, namely, the Labour Ordinance, the Shop Assistants Employment Ordinance and the Clerks Employment Ordinance, all categories of piece-rated workers who are working under a contract of service enjoy exactly the same protection as others employed on a salary basis. Only persons employed as independent contractors, that is to say, workers over whose work the person employing them has no control, are not covered by the law.

NIGHT CLUB ENTERTAINMENT
PROGRAMMES


    10. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs whether he is aware that some entertainment programmes presented in night clubs are contrary to the Government's policy of promoting healthy culture, and what steps he proposes to take in the matter.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the policy of Government in respect of entertainment programmes in high-class hotels or night clubs frequented by tourists is that the standards of censorship will be relaxed to those in general application in large metropolitan towns, for example, London, Tokyo, Bangkok and so on. As it is very unlikely that a great number of people in Singapore can afford to frequent such high-class hotels or night clubs, the promotion of a healthy culture in Singapore will not be affected by this relaxation.

Column: 617



    As regards censorship standards of stage shows open to the general public either in second-rate hotels or night clubs or in cabarets, theatres or cinemas, the present rigid standards will continue to be maintained.

    As soon as I am aware that some entertainment programmes in night clubs are contrary to this policy, steps will be taken to direct the organisers concerned to comply with these standards, and if they do not comply, the usual deposit of $1,000 may be forfeited and/or the licence cancelled.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): I would like to ask the Minister whether he knows what kind of contents is injected into the entertainment programmes presented at the moment in first-class and second-class or, for that matter, third-class hotels and night clubs.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Sir, it is very difficult for me to say what kind of content is injected into the programmes.

    An hon. Member: I wish you knew.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: I wish I knew, yes. But every programme put up for the public to see is first scrutinised by the police and our censors.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware that one of the programmes at the present moment includes striptease acts. Will the Minister see that before any night club proprietor puts up a programme it must be scrutinised very closely by the police department?

    An hon. Member: By the Minister.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Yes, every programme is scrutinised. I would like to sit on the Board if it is possible.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Alleged malpractices in building construction)


    11. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he has requested the Housing and Development Board to furnish him with full information on (a) alleged malpractices

Column: 618

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau is at present conducting investigations into certain alleged malpractices in building construction carried out by the Housing and Development Board. No disciplinary or other action has as yet been taken because the investigations are not complete.

    I am satisfied with the progress of the investigations which are being carried out very thoroughly, but have been impeded by certain natural obstacles. At this stage, it would not be appropriate for me to say what information or evidence has so far been obtained because the investigations may be prejudiced.

    However, Mr Speaker, Sir, I expect to be able soon to make a fuller statement on the matter when the investigations are completed.

BUKIT HO SWEE FLATS
(Conversion into self-contained flats with toilet facilities)


    12. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will request the Housing and Development Board to consider the possibility of converting the existing 900 Bukit Ho Swee flats, which have common lavatory facilities, into self-contained flats each with its own toilet facilities, or alternatively, the reduction of the rent of such flats.

Column: 619



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board has considered the possibility of converting the existing Bukit Ho Swee one-room units with communal facilities into self-contained one-room or two-room units.

    There are altogether 904 units of one-room service communal flats sited in five blocks. The conversion will involve making structural alterations and substantial foundation costs, the cost of which will be prohibitive and not economically justifiable. The rent of these flats is already low - $20 per month - and it is not economically feasible to reduce the rental.

    The Government subsidy for these one-room units already averages as high as $17 per month per unit. Any further reduction in rental will therefore require a corresponding increase in subsidy.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): I would like to ask the Minister whether he has given some thought to the residents of the 900 flats in this area. I would also like to ask him whether he is aware that there are three urgencies in life. The first urgency is beyond control, and that is one must go to the lavatory. The lavatories are situated in a common corridor. So the women who want to go there must be escorted by their husbands, otherwise they have to use a spittoon as a temporary lavatory.

    I would like to find out from the Minister whether he remembers that last year there was an unfortunate incident relating to a small girl in this area because there are no self-contained lavatories. This child was victimised and killed after having gone to the common lavatory.

    In view of the answer given by the Parliamentary Secretary, I would like to ask him whether he is prepared to convert the existing flats for the use of male residents only, or as quarters for men, and the present tenants may be given some other accommodation with self-contained lavatories and kitchens.
